conclusion: Analyzing how the ideal gas changes from state B to state C and calculating the work done during this process.
State A: (V0, p0), State B: (V0, 0.6p0), State C: (0.5V0, 0.6p0).
The process from B to C occurs at constant pressure (0.6p0) with the volume decreasing from V0 to 0.5V0.
Recall the formula for work in a thermodynamic process at constant pressure: W = p * Î”V.
Calculate the work for process B to C: W_{B -> C} = 0.6p0 * (-0.5V0) = -0.3p0V0.
The negative sign indicates that work is done on the gas as the volume decreases.
Express work done by the gas: W_{B -> C, by gas} = -(-0.3p0V0) = 0.3p0V0.
Correction: The work done BY the gas during compression is negative. So the work done BY the gas during the process B to C is: W_{B -> C, by gas} = -0.3p0V0.
The work done by the gas when it changes from state B to state C is -0.3p0V0.
